headline.main: The Big City; The Needle Trade

docs.abstract: John Tierney column on booming business at Lower East Side Needle Exchange, where addicts can get clean needles paid for by New York's AIDS Institute; photo; reports that he and local community board member were able to obtain dozens of syringes at a time, without question, contrary to official policy; notes similar programs have not been successful in other cities; suggests AIDS activists extend some of their compassion to neighborhood beyond their clients (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It takes a refined sensibility to fathom the taboos on Avenue C between Third and Fourth Streets. A new city law bans X-rated businesses from this block of the East Village, since there are churches and apartment buildings nearby. Smoking, too, is pretty much out of the question, at least inside stores and businesses. Soon, if city officials go ahead with their plan to ban tobacco advertising within 1,000 feet of a school, it will be illegal even to put a cigarette sign inside one of these stores. All in all, it is not a good block for vice unless you're interested in mainlining heroin. In that case, the government is ready to help out, as I discovered at the Lower East Side Needle Exchange, a storefront operation largely financed by the state's AIDS Institute. I went there with Nancy Sosman, a legal secretary and former member of the local community board who has been crusading against the needle exchange since she found addicts shooting up in her backyard. We originally intended just to take a look inside, but when a friendly young man on the staff greeted us, we pretended to be heroin addicts.
